questions.text: A man who works as a sewage cleaner comes to the emergency with complaints of fever, conjunctival suffusion and elevated WBC . Investigation of choice is:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Microscopic agglutination test THE HISTORY SUGGESTS leptospirosis which is commonly associated with sewage workers. Rodents are the most important reservoir- rats commonest worldwide source. Transmission occurs when people come into contact with infected animal urine, g. canoeing, swimming in lakes and rivers, farming, Sewage exposure. It is primarily a disease of tropical and subtropical regions, and infection in temperate regions is uncommon. Serology-the mainstay of diagnosis. Commercial tests using genus specific antigens are used to screen sera, and positive reactions confirmed in a reference laboratory using the micro- agglutination test (MAT) with live Leptospira (killed have lower sensitivity). The MAT detects agglutinating antibodies in patient serum and is relatively serovar- specific, so a large number of antigens must be tested.

questions.text: A resident of West Rajasthan presents with erythematous nodule on leg, h&e stain shows 2-4mu round cell with kinetoplast in phagocyte, diagnosis:
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Leishmania tropica The history explains cutaneous leishmania and h&e explains the LD body. The other options are incorrect.

Highyeild:

Cutaneous leishmaniasis is also widely distributed. The classic form of Old World cutaneous leishmaniasis, the oriental sore, is found in the Middle East, the Mediterranean, Africa, India, and Asia. It is caused by major, L. tropica, Leishmania aethiopica , and occasionally by L. donovani and L. infantum. New World cutaneous leishmaniasis is endemic in Latin America. It is caused by Leishmania brazilensis, Leishmania mexicana Leishmania panamensis, and occasionally by L. chagasi. Incubation period 2 weeks- few months. A wide variety of skin lesions may occur, from small, dry, crusted lesions (usually L. tropica) to large, deep ulcers with a granulating base and overlying exudate (usually L. braziliensis). Lesions may be single or multiple and tend to occur on exposed areas. LD BODY: The LD bodies, of size 2-4u, consisted of a nucleus and a smaller kinetoplast, were present within macrophages and occasionally extracellularly.

Stool antigen The diagnosis of rotavirus can be rapidly done by stool antigen test usually done by immunochromatographic test. Rotavirus- Three antigenically distinguishable groups (A to C) cause the human disease. Virtually all outbreaks worldwide are caused by group A organisms. It is found worldwide. Infectious dose — less than equal to 100 organisms . Transmission is faeco- oral (contaminated food or water, direct contact, or inhalation of aerosol from vomit or faeces), and virus is shed for up to a week after symptom onset.

questions.text: A man from Bihar presents with fever, splenomegaly on microscopy organism with kinetoplast was seen . What's the agent?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Leishmania donovani The question explains a typical clinical picture of leishmania and typical microscopic LD body description. Bihar is an endemic area in India for visceral leishmania.

Highyeild:

Visceral leishmaniasis – worldwide distribution. It is caused by Leishmania donovani spp. (India, Pakistan, Nepal, East Africa, Eastern China), Leishmania infantum (Middle East, Mediterranean, Balkans, central and SouthWest Asia, North and West China, North and sub- Saharan Africa), or Leishmania chagasi (Latin America). i ncubation period 3– 8 months. Onset – acute or gradual. Symptoms – abdominal enlargement, fever, weakness, anorexia, and weight loss. Examination shows pallor, hepatosplenomegaly ± lymphadenopathy. The skin becomes dry, thin, scaly, and discoloured (kala- azar = black fever). Secondary infections are common in advanced disease and may lead to death. Laboratory findings include renal impairment, anaemia, leucopenia, and hypergammaglobulinemia. Treatment– Liposomal Amphotericin B, sodium stibogluconate and meglumine antimoniate, miltefosine, etc.
